**The Masterclass** 🎖️ 

Module 4 - "Long Term" 🕙

In the Masterclass we are starting with the technique most likely to make you money in the long run.

Long term investing requires the least amount of things to go right, and the activity itself is fundamentally biased in your favor.

In the investing series we covered how ‘beta/passive/long-term’ was the ideal way of grouping of these principles.

Here in the masterclass I will take you through the steps required to form a sensible long term strategy.

***Agenda ***

> > Define time horizon
> > Classify importance of asset selection over technique
> > How we will look at asset selection
> > What technique we will use (S.DCA)
> > How we will time our technique (Aggregate valuation scoring)
> > Speed of buying and selling (Requires knowledge of the future)

•




Define time horizon (BTC)

•




Define time horizon (ETH)

•




Define magnitude (BTC)

•




Define magnitude (ETH)

***Why Long only?***

> We will not be exploring shorting as the whole point of long term investing is to take advantage of cryptos positive skew

> There is no skew on the downside

***Importance of asset selection over technique for long term:***

> "In long term, the asset does the work for you. In medium term, the asset is just the vehicle for the technique" - Prof Adam
> 
> As you can see from the BTC and ETH example, extreme gains can be made. But more can be made if you choose the right asset.
> 
> If you believe that ETH is going to outperform BTC, you wouldn’t hold BTC.
> 
> If you believe SONIC-OBAMA token is going to outperform ETH & BTC you wouldn’t buy either right?
> 
> This is the *black hole* all new investors fall into. Buying absolute shit because they hope it has more upside based off nothing but some propaganda.
> 
> In the investing series we will be covering *Modern Portfolio Theory* and using it to select the optimal assets.
> 
> MPT is the best quantitative method for selecting assets, and I will be showing you not only how to use it, but how to also improve it.

***What technique we will use (S.DCA)***

> The technique we will use to invest in our assets will be Strategic Dollar Cost Averaging

> This is where you’ll be using indicators to value BTC then buy dollar cost averaging when the value is sensible

> This is the highest likelihood method of accurately buying the dip

***How we will time our technique (Aggregate valuation scoring)***

> Using the principles we have learned in the statistics section, we will perform a wide array of valuation analysis.

> We will combine valuation scores to increase accuracy via Z-scoring

***Speed of buying and selling (Requires knowledge of the future)***

> Rate of buying and selling will be the most difficult and least accurate part of the long term series, as to know the correct speed, by definition we must know the future. Which is impossible.

> We can make some rough approximation, however they will only be guides

***Example of entire process:***

> 1. Do a whole market asset selection analysis using good principles of quantitative asset selection
> 
> 2. Decide ideal portfolio weights
> 
> 3. Conduct indicator research
> 
> 4. Score & Aggregate long term indicators
> 
> 5. Adjust portfolio allocations based on valuations
> >> If valuations are good, increase size
> >> If valuations are neutral, hold
> >> If valuations are bad, decrease size
> 
> 6. The speed at which you increase or decrease positions will be determined by current market conditions

***What can go wrong?***

There’s not much that can go wrong in long term investing aside from lost opportunity cost.

This is an important principle. Opportunity cost is defined as the opportunity that you didn’t take.

When you’re committed for a long time in one investment you might be closing yourself off to other quality investments.

However with enough research you should be able to select the best opportunity from *day 1.*

***What can go right?***

> Long term investing is how the majority of people become millionaires from asset trading & management

> The psyop that you can day trade your way to millions is not true for the majority of people

> The majority of people can become rich easily using long term investing, it only requires patience.

> With patience, 10x your money is basically guaranteed, you have to not fuck it up

***Summary***

> We’re going to approach long term investing from the beta/passive/long-term angle

> In order of importance we will look at
> > Asset selection
> > Long Term Valuation
> > Strategic dollar cost averaging based on valuation

> Long term investing is the most likely method that will make you rich

•




> **The Masterclass 26**
>

***Asset Selection (MPT basics)***

> In the investing lessons we covered the basics of quantitative asset selection.

> The quality of an asset is derived from its risk-adjusted performance, which is a ratio of its performance divided by risk.

> We discussed how NO RATIONAL investor would willingly choose an asset that didn’t maximise this relationship.

> In this unit I will show you how to perform the asset analysis and selection process.

•




***‘Expected return’*** is simply the historical return

•




***‘Standard Deviation’***

We’ve covered a lot here, but the main takeaway is that MPT is the ideal way of understanding how asset selection should work, and the quality it provides us.

***In Summary***

> Correlation renders broad diversification mostly useless.

> In a competitive market, a rational investor will only hold the optimal portfolio.

> Because correlation is so high, this statement can be modified: In a competitive, highly correlated cryptocurrency market, a rational investor will only hold the optimal ASSET/s.

> In this presentation, ETH was given the highest sharpe ratio as a hypothetical example, because of this, it would be the ‘optimal asset’ in traditional MPT.

The optimal asset is always changing, so there will be an appendix showing how to perform this analysis after the next lecture.

***Appendix:*** Unedited pre-release MPT explainer:

•




> **The Masterclass 27**
>

***Asset Selection Agenda (MPT Advanced)***

> If MPT is good, then how can we improve it?

> Failure of Standard Deviation in favor of Semi-Deviation (“PMPT”)

> Failure of Semi-D (does not take into account the ‘nature’ of the risk)

> Improve using a probability density function

> “Ultimate portfolio theory”

> How I go about selecting assets (screencap of TV & Spreadsheet)

***Problem?***

> We already know MPT is useful for selecting the optimal asset. But it has a major flaw.

> The sharpe ratio is a wonderful measurement for giving context to risk and reward, but there is a problem in the way it measures risk.

> Risk according to the standard deviation of returns actually measures volatility in both directions by definition.

•




Using ***‘Standard Deviation’*** in the sharpe ratio punishes up and down variance equally

•




Wouldn't it be great if we had something that only punished the negative deviations?

•




WE DO ~ Its called the ***SORTINO RATIO******!***

It’s the same as the sharpe ratio, but it only punishes negative variance

•




How they look:

•




There is another problem: ***Semi-Deviation*** only gives you a one dimensional measure of risk.

•




Wouldn’t it be better if we had a measure that took into account ALL the behavior of the risk?

•




What about a ratio that took into account all the behavioral information about all the risks and all rewards? It would be the ultimate ratio, no data would be wasted.

•




In this example, neither standard deviation or semi-deviation would give us useful information

•




But the ***Omega ratio*** does!

•




Now it doesn’t matter what the distribution is shaped like! Every possible data point is now accounted for! This is good because crypto often behaves extremely weird.

Because no other ratio can possibly contain more information on the nature of risk and reward, it is known as ‘omega’ because it is the ultimate.

•




For the record, you will often find the behavior quite similar to the sortino ratio

•




Simplified

***What can go wrong when using the Omega ratio?***

> You may encounter results with this method that don’t make sense, or are counterintuitive.

> Results from the omega ratio might end up being biased due to extreme gains (10,000%+) and the limit of an asset to ‘only’ go down -100%.

> Infinite upside skew.

> Never forget that much like all data, its backwards looking and tells you nothing about the future, just about the historical behavior.

> It might be worthwhile considering the results in the context of some qualitative analysis to temper extreme results.

***Summary***

> MPT uses the sharpe ratio, but it punishes both upwards variation and downwards variation

> The sortino ratio improves on this and only punishes negative deviations

> The omega ratio improves on this again and forms a theoretically perfect probability density ratio of all wins and all losses, and because of this, it is the best ratio for asset selection.

> Conclusions stemming from the omega ratio might end up being biased due to extremely skewed gains.

https://www.tradingview.com/script/J1aP07iJ-Rolling-Risk-Adjusted-Performance-Ratios/

> **The Masterclass 28**
>

***DCA***

> In the dollar cost average lecture we reviewed the brilliance of DCA’ing, and how it gets you the best value over time for no additional research.

> Clearly we are enterprising investors, so we will add additional information into the strategy to increase the profitability

***Refresher - How it works:***

> You buy a fixed dollar amount of the asset each time period (day, month, hour; it doesn't matter).

> If you think the last point is overly simplified, you're right. We could argue semantics amount timing to infinity, we will not do that today.

> Due to the investor automatically buying more UNITS of the asset when prices are low vs when prices are high, the natural volatility of the asset helps the investor to get better value for money.

•




Obviously the problem with DCA is that it also tells you to buy high and makes no consideration for sales.

•




The logical thing to do is to only DCA into positions when there is good value. This will exponentially increase the effectiveness of our dollar allocations because we won’t be buying high.

•




Furthermore, we’ll also be using information to sell high and lock in profits.

So in summary… 

YOUR STUPID ASS MISSED TWO KEY PROBLEMS

You thought this lecture was over didn’t you? Guess again!!!

1. What about the capital left over in case there is not enough time/opportunities to deploy all your capital?

2. What do we do with extra cashflow that you keep earning after you've finished accumulating?

***What about the capital left over in case there is not enough opportunities to deploy all the capital?***

> If we have $10,000 and we’ve only deployed $8,000, what do we do with the remaining $2000 now that we’re not in the value zone anymore?

> Think back to Price analysis principles - Trigger of trend condition

> If were coming out of high value, there is a high probability that we’ll be higher in the future, therefore dumping all the remaining capital into the market as a lump sum is the logical thing to do

> This is the effective marriage of LSI and DCA working together

•




This is what it should look like

***What do we do with the extra cashflow?***

> You keep investing it obviously, it's not going to have a very powerful effect, but what else are you going to do? Sit on your dick?

> Invest additional cashflow into small caps over time moving down the market cap ladder.

> They get the majority of their gains at the end of the bull market anyway so who cares

•




Therefore your complete long term investing strategy should look like this

•




***“Beyond the efficient frontier”*** ~ Knowing when to use leverage

•




***RELATED:*** Knowing when to use beta

***Summary*** (for real this time)

> DCA is an ideal long term strategy which can be enhanced by additional data.

> We can make considerations for leftover capital and additional purchases by invoking new rules to enhance SDCA.

> Accumulate when there’s high value

> LSI when we have a positive macro condition

> Continue to DCA over time into progressively smaller-caps, but do not DCA on the downside of bear markets

> Light leverage is permissible to take investors beyond the efficient frontier, but only when downside is limited (high value)

> NEITHER THE CORRECT ASSET SELECTION, NOR CONSERVATIVE LEVERAGE WILL SAVE YOU FROM ANNIHILATION IF YOU GET YOUR TIMING WRONG. You must actually time your investments correctly.

***What are we doing here...***

> Were going to spend a bit of time going through each one and showing you approximately how I’d score them.

Core Principle

***Ok so now you know how to judge the relative value of each indicator***

> The question will come up: ‘why are we giving them subjective numbers instead of objective numbers if the human brain is so dangerous?’

> If you understand it conceptually enough, then you should be able to eye-ball it with accuracy even if you’re slightly biased.

> The average of your errors should even out the result

> No one is going to spend weeks trying to value every indicator using propper math when you can do it instantly with your eyes.

> With that being said, you could spend the time to program it and then automate it and that would be a huge benefit.

***Summary***

> Use Z-scores to judge the values of your indicators so they can all be aggregated.

> The average errors of your guesses should even out the final result.

> In my opinion this means a subjective judgement of the z-scores is sufficient, rather than doing it mathematically, which would be extremely complex to perform correctly.

> **The Masterclass 31** 
>

***Valuation Concepts***

> The real magic of valuation scoring comes from ‘standardization’

> This is the process of using the Z-score to compare multiple things which could previously never be compared.

> Remember that the Z-score is a standard measurement of the significance of any variation in any data-set.

> Therefore getting an a complete valuation score is as easy as taking an average of all the z-scores

•




The principle should be super fucking obvious at this point.

We don't know which indicator is correct, because they all work differently, so we just take a simple average of all the inputs.

> **The Masterclass 32** 
>

***Introduction***

> Despite its power, there is a fundamental paradox in SDCA.

> We need to know how fast to accumulate without knowing how much time we have to accumulate, because the future cannot be known.

> Do you go 1% per day? 2% per day? 10% per week? 5% every 2 days?

> Ideally, you’d want to deploy all of your capital while price is in a ‘high value’ zone to get the best entries on average.

> Said another day, the goal is to have no cash left over by the time the market starts rising into the next bull market.

***The fundamental SDCA conundrum***

> If you buy too fast, you’ll run out of cash, and might miss out on better opportunities if the price keeps dipping.

> If you go too slow, you’ll have too much cash left as the market starts to rise, and your final entry price will be too high.

> Too slow is marginally preferred over too fast due to the conservation of opportunity cost (meaning you keep your cash for longer) and the fact positive trend LSI will still likely provide good results.

•

How did I perform the calculation for expected bear market days in this cycle? 

(NOT a direct recommendation to use this method. It’s just an idea. There is no ‘secret’ way of knowing the future. Don't be naive)

Linear regression of market trends plus standard deviation of residuals = average of 145 days & SD of 27 for the bear market in the year 2027 (or ‘phase’ 5 as I have called it).

***Example:***

> This means if you wanted to run down your 1,000,000$ cash account to zero by the end of an average bear market and hold 100% crypto, you’d buy:
> 
> $1,000,000 / 145 days = $6,896.55 per day for 145 days.
> 
> This is also 0.69% per day.
> 
> However depending on some additional analysis you could always make a judgement call on whether you think the SD of the bear market accumulation period will be on the long side (+1SD = 172d), or on the short side (-1SD = 117d).

***Important considerations***

> As you can see, this method uses calculation and historical data, which by definition, is lagging and probably doesn’t contain any information about the future.
> 
> It also only uses a sample size of only 3 complete bear markets, and one incomplete bear market (time of recording) which is bad data analysis, but it’s the only data we have.
> 
> We also don’t know if bear market valuation-duration is stationary or non-stationary? Should I have performed a simple average and not a regression? No one knows because we don’t know the future.

***Summary***

> What I have shown you here is not an accurate way of forecasting bear market durations because NO ONE KNOWS the right method. Its intrinsically unknowable. Rate of accumulation is a best-guess activity. 

> This means you should not blindly accept this method as ‘best’ simply because I use it. You should strive to create a better method and develop them yourself.

> At the end of the day, bull markets in crypto are so big that generally even if you miss the bottom and LSI on an upwards trend, you’ll do very well.

> This means, getting your accumulation approximately correct is really ‘good enough’.

> **The Masterclass 33** 
>

***Rate of Distribution Introduction***

> Exactly like the accumulation lesson, there is no way of knowing how fast to “distribute” our sales because the future is intrinsically unknowable.
> 
> Rate of distribution is exponentially harder to plan than accumulation because the upper bounds of price do not exist. This is why when BTC is going up it is known as ‘price discovery’.
> 
> I have not come up with a robust forecasting method for the rate of sales, so instead of providing a method, this lecture will simply supply some ideas for you to consider.

•




Most obvious robust criteria: valuations >80 on the CBBI or maybe values above -1.5 or -2 on the Macro Bitcoin spreadsheet

•




Issues with alpha-decay and front-running: Unless you have a way of dynamically range adjusting the data, your estimations will become increasingly less accurate over time.

•




I always looked at this chart and thought to myself, isn’t it ironic that ATH’s is when most people keep saying ‘we’ve broken out!’ when in reality it’s some of the best times to sell?

•




Combining ATH days/weeks with valuation would be an optimal strategy.

***"But what if we sell at ATH’s and it keeps going up?"***

Of course it will.

You’re being conditioned in a pavlovian manner to not sell with each ATH, because every time you hesitate, it actually keeps going up, and you’re implicitly rewarded for inaction and fear.

This keeps happening until it stops going up, and then crashes, but of course by then it’s too late. You're married to your bags.

This means no single ATH will actually signal the top in forward testing, however most ATH’s, on average, do represent an optimal selling location.

•




***Different methods of taking profit per ATH when the asset is still growing. (SDCA exit speed)***

Underlying assumption: Asset is still growing at some random speed.

(This would be more accurate if the CAGR for each bull run could be calculated and then input as one of the model assumptions.)

Linear+2 = 1 +2 +2 each time
Expon = 1\2 \2 each time
Incr1 = 1+2+3+4
Incr2 = 1+2+4+6
Incr\1.1 = 1\+10%\*+10%

None of these hypothetical speeds will work well in forward testing because we have no idea how fast the bull market will be rising into the future.

•




Personally, I believe the single largest determinant of top formation is actually raw net profit. 

Think conceptually:
I.e. if people are sitting on tons of profits, they are more likely to sell, thus placing a natural upper limit on how high price can go due to the desire of people to spend.

If you have $10 million in crypto, is your ass going to leave that shit in the market, or are you going to cash out and live your life?

Sell pressure measured by the NUPL indicator I think should theoretically be resistant to alpha decay. But nothing is truly perfect.

***Qualitative: Look for mass euphoria and classic social signs that BTC has peaked***

> Uber-eats/pizza delivery kids becoming rich.

> Most young people are talking about quitting their job to ‘Trade’ full time.

> People are talking about the cars they want to buy.

> Grandparents are buying shitcoins.

> Old people, who previously knew nothing about finance, now are looking to convert all their assets to cryptos.

> Rapid clustering of celebrities promoting crypto projects. (Personal favorite)

***Qualitative: Persistent Macro Factors***

> In the last cycle, the bull market began to fade along with central bank balance sheets.
> 
> If you have the ability to keep an eye on this, you might broadly detect cycle tops, but it would not be very precise.

•




***CURVE BALL***

The hyperbolic model is a great example of what can go wrong if we use valuations and ATH’s to classify tops in a mean-reversion manner rather than trend-following manner. 

Valuations might be high, then you sell all your positions right before BTC goes to infinity.

While this model is a SUPER MEGA TIN FOIL HAT idea, it serves as a great thought experiment about the limitations of valuation alone.

•




We might be in the unlikely timeline where fiat money goes to zero and nothing matters except BTC.

Under these circumstances it would be good to have a long term trend model as well to manage your positions.

To validate this model you'd want to see things like hyperinflation in developed countries, which while unlikely, could still happen.

•




***A potential solution to the long term 'trend' problem***

My long term bull/bear model contains:
> Technical trend factors
> Macroeconomic factors
> Market cap trend factors
> Seasonal factors
> and…
> Frequency cycle factors

These are all combined in an attempt to give context to the locations where the market might pivot from bull to bear…
More on this method in the medium-term unit.

***Summary***

> Selling the top is very hard to do, and your best approach is to be ‘approximately correct’ by scaling out over time, rather than ‘exactly incorrect’ and trying to top-tick the cycle.

> Personally I use a combination of valuation, ATH’s, trend and qualitative analysis to determine if it's time to sell.

> Whole-market quantitative valuation analysis is likely least subject to errors, but could also be the most sensitive to front-running & alpha decay.

> There is a non-zero chance that BTC will go to infinity in the next 10 years, and valuation analysis will cause you to sell early. Weight the probability of this unlikely scenario appropriately, i.e. 90% sales based on valuation analysis, 10% based on trend analysis.

***Valuation Indicators***

> Use Z-scores to judge the values of your indicators so they can all be aggregated.

> The average errors of your guesses should even out the final result

> In my opinion this means a subjective judgement of the z-scores is sufficient, rather than doing it mathematically, would would be extremely complex to perform correctly

•




***Valuation Aggregation/Scoring***

> Z-scores allow statistically valid probabilistic aggregation

> The average of your Z-scores should be equally weighted to eliminate estimation error

> Select high quality fundamental indicators where possible

> Don’t mix too many short term indicators with long term

> This sheet I provide you is NOT complete. Don’t be lazy. Get out there and find more indicators

***Rate of Accumulation***

> What I have shown you here is not the right way of forecasting bear market values because NO ONE KNOWS the right method. Its intrinsically unknowable. Rate of accumulation is a best-guess activity.

> This means you should not blindly accept this method as ‘best’ simply because I use it. You should strive to create a better method.

> At the end of the day, bull markets in crypto are so big that generally even if you miss the bottom and LSI on an upwards trend, you’ll do very well.

> This means, getting your accumulation approximately correct is really ‘good enough’.

By using the CBBI chart and some principles from the stats lessons I found that the average period I could consider ‘DCA-able value’ to be on average 114 days for each bear market, with a standard deviation of 32 days.

•




***Rate of Distribution***

> Selling the top is very hard to do, and your best approach is to be ‘approximately correct’ by scaling out over time, rather than ‘exactly incorrect’ and trying to top-tick the cycle.

> Personally I use a combination of valuation, ATH’s, trend and qualitative analysis to determine if it's time to sell.

> Whole-market quantitative valuation analysis is likely least subject to errors, but could also be the most sensitive to front-running & alpha decay.

> There is a non-zero chance that BTC will go to infinity in the next 10 years, and valuation analysis will cause you to sell early. Weight the probability of this unlikely scenario appropriately, i.e. 90% sales based on valuation analysis, 10% based on trend analysis.
